snippet: A partial statue unearthed in southeastern Turkey depicts Suppiluliuma, who ruled in the ninth century B.C.
abstract: Team of archaeologists from the University of Toronto discover a giant statue of a Turkish king that dates back 3,000 years; piece, found in southeastern Turkey, demonstrates that creativity and intellect flourished in the Iron Age despite the absence of big empires. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Archaeologists working in Turkey have discovered a giant statue of a Neo-Hittite king that dates back 3,000 years.The partly broken sculpture of the king's head and torso stands nearly five feet tall, and the full sculpture may have been more than 10 feet, said Timothy P. Harrison , an archaeologist from the University of Toronto who was part of the team that made the discovery .

headline.main: Iron Age Creativity In a Turkish King's Image
